p.seg: The gāthā says:
The body receives life (is born) from no-mark,lg==
Comparable to an illusion who brings forth all kinds of shapes and images.lg==
The magician's mind and consciousness is originally empty;lg==
Guilt and good fortune (merit) are both empty and without a anything to abide in.lg==
The gāthā says:
To produce all good dharmas is fundamentally an illusion;
To create bad karma is as well an illusion.
The body is like accumulated foam, the mind is like wind;
What is produced by illusion is without base and without real nature.
The gāthā says:
Making use of the Four Elements the body is made;
The mind is fundamentally unborn (unproduced) and only exists depending on external objects.
As for the manifest objects, if there is no mind then the object likewise does not exist,
Guilt and good fortune arise and perish like illusions.
The gāthā says:
To understand that the body is without substance is to realise the Buddha;
To understand that the mind is like an illusion is to understand the Buddha.
The one who is able to understand that the fundamental nature of body and mind is empty -
how can this (such a CH) person be different from Buddha?
The gāthā says:
Buddha, although not seeing his body, one knows that it is the Buddha;
If one really has wisdom, then one knows that there is no other Buddha.
The wise are able to know that the nature of guilt is empty,
Being at ease, not afraid of life and death.
The gāthā says:
The nature of all living beings is pure;
from the beginning (fundamentally) they are unborn (not produced) and [therefore] cannot be destroyed.
Since this body and mind are born from illusion,
In illusionary transformations there is no guilt or good fortune.
The gāthā says:
Illusionary transformations are without cause and unborn (not produced),
Although they all [seem to] appear naturally like this. /s4Hi)/
All the dharmas are not non-existing [but] born through transforming themselves (self-transformation),
Illusionary transformation is unborn (not produced) and there is nothing to fear.ì /?yj)/[?]
This Śākya-Buddha
was the fourth Buddha in the present Bhadra kalpa.
Among the three kalpas,
[as for] the initial thousand Buddhas,
Padmaprabha Buddha was the first,
until [the last] Viśvabhū Buddha,
who in the past Vyūha kalpa managed to become Buddhas.
Among the thousand Buddhas of the middle period (i.e. the present kalpa)
Koṇḍañña Buddha was the first,
down to Rucika Tathāgata,
who in the present Bhadra kalpa one after the other will become Buddhas.
Among the thousand Buddhas of the future period,
the first will be Sūrya-prabha Buddha,
down to Sumerulakṣaṇa Buddha [??],
who in the future Naksatra kalpa shall become Buddhas.
At the beginning of the Bhadra kalpa
scented water was flowing everywhere,
and in the middle there was a huge Lotus-flower with thousand stems.
The kings in the fourth dhyāna-level99
looked at this auspicious sign
and one after the other said :
"Now, when this world is formed,
thousand wise (xián 賢) men (i.e. Buddhas) shall appear in it."
Therefore,
this time period is called the Badra (xián 賢 'Wise') kalpa.
According to the Yīn-gǔo jīng it is said:100
"Śākya Tathāgata, at the time when he had not yet become a Buddha,
was a great Bodhisattva
by name of Shànhùi ('Good Wisdom'),
and he was also referred to as Rěnrǔ ('Enduring Disgrace').
When he had already fulfilled his meritorious deeds (practices),
and his rank had risen to 'candidate for the next Buddha',101
he was born in the Tuṣīta Heaven102
where he was called Shèngshàn ('Saintly Good'),
or alternatively Hùmíng ('Protecting Brightness').
To all the heavenly kings he taught the practice of a Buddha-candidate
and he also appeared in the ten directions in order to expound the dharma.
The time of good fortune was abot to arrive
when he would descend and become a Buddha.
He checked which of all the countries was the most central
and got to know that the city of Kapilavastu was the center of the earth."
So the Běnqǐ jīng says:
"The supernatural powers (awe-inspiring numinousness) of the Buddha
were highly honoured and regarded as of paramount importance,
and he could not be born [remote] place (lit. slope) of a border area.
This city of Kapilavastu,
is the center of heaven and earth and the three thousand suns and moons.
All the past Buddhas
were born (lit. flourished) here."
The Abidharmakośa śāstra says:
"[Kapilavastu] is the center of the jambū continent."
The Shānhǎi jīng says:
"The country of the Sindhu (Indus)
is where the Xuānyuán clan resides."
The Guópú commentary says:113
"Thus the center is India.114
That country is naturally divided into five Indian states,
Central India being the center of heaven and earth.
Since the name suggests that it is not a border area
the meaning 'central' is apparent."
The Yīnguǒ jīng says:
"In Central India and Bactria there are four castes
which are called the royal (imperial) Kṣatriya caste, the Brāhmaṇa caste,
the Vaiśya caste, and the Śūdra caste.
The royal Kṣatriya caste is the most exalted and noble one;
since the beginning of the kalpa
they succeeded each other without interruption.
The remaining three castes
will not be discussed here,
but [we] only elucidate on the caste of the Buddha,
which divided itself into five different [clans]."
The Dīrghāgama sūtra furthermore says:121
"When the kalpa in the beginning took form,
there was no light of the moon or sun yet.
When the Gods' good fortune was used up they were born below [on earth]
and all of them transformed into human beings.
Joy served as their food122
and the light of their bodies was shinging into the far distance.
They walked as if flying and they were unrestrained,
there was no [difference between] men and women, exalted and low, family relations and cliques.
There was a natural flavour of the earth [naturally, the earth gave off a flavour]
which was like Sūmì.
There was somebody who tried [to eat it]
and consequently [people] began to fight for food;
The power of the light vanished in the end
and screaming and sighing they existed on earth (and there was screaming and sighing on earth). [??]
The bodily appearance of those who had eaten very much became emaciated
and the shape of those who had eaten little became fat,
and [the notion of] gain and loss was coming into existence.
The flavour of the earth then disappeared.
Furthermore, a 'skin' of the earth appeared.
Because they ate the 'skin' of the earth
all kinds of evils were accumulated.
Furthermore, forests, climbing plants,128 rice and hulled grains came into existence,
and all the flavours were sweet and delightful.
Because of this food the reproductive organs of men and women were implemented;129
and like this they tossed and turned [made love to each other ?],
then they became relatives by marriage,
and consequently for the first time a foetus was born."
The Lokasthāna sūtra says:
"The naturally growing rice,
was cut down and harvested in the morning it and in the evening had ripened [again]."
The Madhyamāgama says:
"The grains of rice were four cùn long,
therefore the people competed with each other to be the first to get hold of them
and like this they killed each other,
and at the places where they got hold of [the rice] first
afterwards it did not grow again."
The Dīrghāgama says:
"At that time the living beings were already aware that [the rice] would not grow back [by itself]
and therefore everybody felt anxieties;
mutually they demarcated their fields and houses
and by means of this created property (lit. demarcated areas, boundaries).
[From the time onwards] they had their own storage rooms
they stole the grain from the fields of others.
Debates arose because of this
and there was nobody who could settle them (judge over the conflicts).
Therefore they deliberated to install a person
called pǐngděng zhǔ 平等主 ('master of fairness/ equality)',
who should give rewards to the good and punish the wicked
and permanently be supplied (i.e. supported) together (i.e. by the community).
At that time there was a person
whose appearance and talents were exceptionally good,
who was awe-inspiring and affectionate towards living beings,
and who was somebody the people trusted and obeyed.
They consequently came and invited him [to take over the position]
and after he had accepted it,
he consequently was called mínzhǔ 民主 ('ruler over the people')."140
The Lokasthāna sūtra says:141
"The people deliberated
to give him an appellation as leader,
and called him 'king'.
Based on the law he collected taxes (cess)
and therefore he was called Kṣatriya,
which is translated into tiāndì zhǔ 田地主('chief of land/landowner')."
At that time, the Jambu-dvīpā42 world was prosperous and peaceful;
the earth brought forth green grass
which resembled peacock feathers.
The settlements of the 80,000 states were close to each other
and there was nobody who suffered from the vexations of [excessive] heat, cold, or sicknesses.
The king ruled the world by means of a correct law
and they practiced the ten good [deeds],
and [king and people] respected each other
like a father and son.
The lifespan of people was extremely long
and cannot be counted.
Afterwards there were other kings
who did not practice the correct law,
and consequently the life-span was reduced to 10,000 years.
Like this the lifespan gradually diminished to the hundred years [common] nowadays.
Prior to the beginning of the kalpa,
there was a king established (or maybe: the founder was a king), ??
and [afterwards] [kings] succeeded one after the other,
down until the Bodhisattva Rahula,146
when the [succession of] legitimate heirs was disrupted;
the other branches of the family are still continuing the position [of king] today.
Therefore, there is a detailed list below with the line of succession (lit. features of continuation) of the Cakra-varti-rājan and the kings of minor importance.
The initial mínzhǔ 民主 king was called Dàrén 大人 ('Great Man'),
the second was King Zhēnbǎo 珍寶 ('Precious Treasure'),
down until the thirty-third King who was called King Shànsī 善思 ('Good Thought').
The above mentioned thirty-three kings were continuously succeeded by their sons;
they are also the Sùsàn (i.e. of great number and of minor importance) and that is all there is to it.
Following below are the holy Wheel-turning Kings:
legitimate heirs succeeding each other,
down until the Bodhisattva [i.e. the later Buddha].
In the Lokasthāna it is said:
"King Zhēnshé had a son (crown prince)
who was called Bōzé(yán)jia."
This translates into 大魚王 'King Big Fish'.
The Fóběn xíng jīng says:
"In Central India there was a city
that was called Bāoduōnǎ.
The people there were abundant
and among them there was an emperor
who was called King Dàyú 大魚 ('Big Fish')."
From this king down to King Dàmíngchéng 大名稱 ('Great Name/Fame')
the sons and grandsons succeeded each other
and the number of descendants was totalled (lit. 'counted') 84,272 kings,
and all of them were Jīnlún ('Golden Wheel[-turning]') kings.
In the very end there were two kings,
[one] was ruler over Jambu-dvīpa
and was called King Mǎocǎo.
He had a son
who was called King Dàmáocǎo (King 'Great Watershield-Grass').
King Dàmáocǎo had no sons who could become king
and he had the following thought:
"My ancestors succeeded each other, generation after generation
and all were descendants of Golden Wheel Kings.
Now I am without heir
and the clan is likely to be disrupted.
If I renounce home
then I am afraid that I disrupt the royal clan;
if I do not renounce home
then I disrupt the clan of the sages."
After having thought this,
he entrusted all affairs of the state to the high officials
and he then went into the mountains in order to practice the Way;
he became an immortal endowed with the five supernatural powers162
and was called Wángxiān ('Royal Immortal').
This Royal Immortal had first a wife
whose name was Shànxí;
who became pregnant in the palace
and afterwards gave birth to a child
who was the descendant of King Dàmáocaǒ.
Afterwards, all the great ministers got to know that he was the son of Royal Immortal
and they consequently legally respectfully??) and formally performed the guàndǐng ceremony.
He continued the position of king.
and his appellation was King Ikṣvāku,
alternatively he was referred to as King Yùmó
and as King Yìmó.
The king had two wives (imperial concubines).170
One was called Shànxián ('Good Virtue').
and the other one was called Miàoduānzhèng ('Handsome').
Miàoduānzhèng
gave birth to four princes.
The first was called Jùmiàn 炬面,
the second Jīnsè 金色,
the third Xiàngzhòng 象眾,
and the fourth Biéchéng 別成.
His [other] wife Shànxián gave birth to only one son
whose name was Chángshòu 長壽 ('Long Life').
He was handsome and lovely
and in the world there were few who could equal him.
But he did not have a good disposition (character)
and was not capable of continuing the position [of a king].
Shànxián had the following thoughts:
"The wonderful and handsome four children,
Jùmiàn and the others,
the flock of elder and younger brothers is numerous.
Now, I have only this one son
and even though he is handsome
he is not capable of becoming king.
What kind of expedient means shall I apply
so my son is able to succeed to the throne?"
At that time
King Ikṣvāku was riding his carriage to the imperial park,
comforting (i.e. paying a visit to ??) his wives (concubines).
Shànxián came out
and instructed the king, saying:
"I enjoy all kinds of commodities
and I only have one wish.
I want to beg [something] from Your Majesty,
and I wished Your Majesty would grant it to me!"
The King said:
"Whatever your heart desires
I shall give it to you."
Shànxián said:
"So your Majesty cannot change his mind (regret),
I ask Your Majesty to make an oath!"
The king said:
"If I change my mind (regret)
I shall be torn into seven pieces!"
Shànxián addressed the great king, saying:
"Your four sons, Jùmiàn and the others,
should be expelled [from the city]!"
The King said:
"These four sons did not commit any offence,
why drive them out?'
The King pondered for a long time
and since he could not reject her wish after he himself had given an oath,
he then judged that the four sons were be exiled to another region.
At that time the four princes addressed their father, saying:
"We four people did not commit any marginal offence
and suddenly you expell us from the state.
What is the reason for this?"
The king said:
"I know that you four sons really are without offence
not being guilty of any crime, you unjustly have to suffer [the fate] I mentioned to you before.
This is not my attitude (basic intention),
but the intention of Shànxián."
After the four sons' biological mother, their followers (or: relatives) and others had heard about this event,
they hurried to the king's place,
addressing the king with the following words:
"If our four children submit to the king ['s order] of expulsion
and we wish to follow them!"
The king said:
"It shall be granted!"
King Ikṣvāku gave the order
and after that he told his four sons:
"If you wish to be married,
do not marry anybody from another clan;
you should approach somebody within the same clan
in order not let our clan be cut off!"
These four sons respected the decree of the king
and thus they led their followers north.
They reached Kapilavastū89 [?]
where the landscape was open and level,
without any holes (low-lying areas) or hills (i.e. the region was flat).
[They] led all followers to live amidst these woods.
Since good fortune and merit [from past lives] was abundant
they consequently became a great city (state).
Later on King Ikṣvāku yearned after them and asked his ministers:
"Formerly I drove away my four sons,
where are they now?"
The senior ministers formally answered:
"Now they are north of Xiāngshān ('Fragrant Mountain')
and south of Xuěshān ('Snow Mountain').191
Between these two mountains there is a forest
which is called Shěyí.
The earth is fertile and productive
and the population became very numerous.
The people [from other places] submitted to them,
[and the place is busy] like a market place;
they gather together to form a great country.
They are formally established as kings
and the capital is called Níjūluó.
It is the place where the old immortal Kapilavastu attained the truth
and based on this they gave this name to the city."
After the king Iikṣvāku had heard this
he several times said with a sigh of admiration:
"My children are virtuous! My children are virtuous!"
Because of this the family name was established from virtue;
[and therefore] their family name was Śākya;
Śākya
means in translation 'the able and benevolent one'.
After the three sons of great King Ikṣvāku had died
there was only Biéchéng left
and he received the appellation King Níjūluó.
He was the first ancestor of the Buddha.
This king had a prince
whose name was King Jūlú.199
and he is the great-great-grandfather of Buddha.
This king had a prince
whose name was King Qújūlú.200
This is Buddha's great-grandfather.
This king had a prince
whose name was King Siṃhahanu,202
that is the grandfather of Buddha.
This king had four princes,
the first was called Śuddhodana,
that is King Jìngfàn.
The second was called Sukkodana,
that is King Báifàn.
The third was called Droṇodana,
that is King Húfàn.
The fourth was called Amṛtodana,
that is King Gānlùfàn.
King Jīngfàn had two princes
one was called Siddharta,
that is Buddha.
He was born on the eighth day of the fourth month
and his body height was one zhàng six [chǐ 尺].
The second was called Nanda,
he was the one 'who sweeps the ground against the wind'; [??]
he was born on the ninth day of the fourth month
and his body height was one zhàng five chǐ and four cùn.
King Báifàn had two princes,
and one was called Devadatta
who is Buddha's elder cousin on the paternal side.
He was born on the seventh day of the fourth month
and his body height was one zhàng five chǐ and four cùn.
The second was called Ananda
and he was the personal attendant of Buddha.
He was born on the tenth day of the fourth month
and his body height was one zhàng five chǐ and three cùn.
King Húfàn had two sons.
One was called Sakkamahānāma,
the one 'who makes earth into gold';
He was born on the twelfth day of the fourth month
and his body height was one zhàng and four cùn.
King Gānlùfàn had two princes,
one was called Bōtóu;
after [Gānlùfàn] had renounced home,
he was born on the thirteenth day of the fourth month;
his body height was one zhàng and four cùn.
The second was called Bhadrika
who entered the Way [i.e. became a monk].
He was born on the forteenth day of the fourth month
and his body height was one zhàng and four cùn.
The Fóběnxíng jīng says:
"At that time
Bodhisattva Hùmíng was up in the Tuṣita heaven
and in his mind he wished to convert (teach) all sentient beings.
Consequently he ordered the god (King) Jīntuán:
'You are good at inspecting the families of all the kings
so you should choose a place of birth for me.
The god (deva) received the order of the Bodhisattva and investigated [the royal families] for him.
After having investigated [them]
he addressed the Bodhisattva, saying:
'There is a Kṣatriya caste
with the family name of Gautama,
who are the descandants of Emperor Kṣatriya.
[One of the ancestors] studied the Way according to the great immortal Gautama
and the family name Gautama derives from this teacher.
From the beginning,
generation after generation they belonged to the clan of Golden Wheel Kings
and since the time of the descendants of King Ikṣvāku,
sons and grandsons succeeded each other
and resided in the city Kapilavastu,225
which was made in a capital by the Śākya clan.
There was a king
by the name of Siṃhahanu.226
This king had a prince
whose name was King Śuddhodana.
Now, as for this king,
he is famous among the gods and men of all the worlds
and deserves to be the place where you, the Bodhisattva, entrusts your brith to.'
The Bodhisattva gasped in admiration, saying:
'Splendid! Splendid!
You are good at investigating all the royal families
and according to what you have said
I have decided to be born there.'"
Furthermore, the scripture says:
"When the Bodhisattva Hùmíng was about to descend [from Tuīta Heaven]
the wife Māyā reported to King Jīngfàn the following:
'The great King should know
that I wish today to undergo the pure fast of the eight prohibitions.'
After having fasted
she then fell sleep.
In a dream she saw a white elephant with six tusks;
its head had the colour of bright red cinnebar
and it was planted (i.e. stood) on the ground with his seven extremeties.
His teeth were decorated with gold.
Gods were riding it,
descending down from the sky,
they hastened to the palace of King Jīngfàn."
According to the Dīrghāgama it is said:
"Calculating (deducing) the Buddha's descendance into the divine mother-womb

this corresponds to this country's fifth Emperor of the Jī Zhōu dynasty, King Zhào, the 23rd year of his accession to the throne, the year guǐchǒu (1020 B.C.!); the fifteenth day of the seventh month, he was reincarnated in the womb of māyā.
In the twenty-fourth year, the year jiǎyín, (1019 B.C.!)
the wife Māyā was entertaining and enjoying herself in the Píluó Park,
when she saw that the blossoms from the willow tree were lovely; 233
she raised her right hand to pull herself up on a twig
and the Bodhisattva was born from her right ribs.
His body had the color of real gold
and he was fully equipped with the [thirty two major] marks and [eighty minor] auspicious [signs]."235
Furthermore the Lalitavistara says:236
"At the time Buddha was born a great light emanated,
illuminating the realms (worlds) of the ten directions.
The earth gushed forth golden Lotus,
which by itself (naturally) lifted up [Buddha's] feet.
To the east, west, south, and north
he walked seven steps into each [direction]
and inspected the four directions;
with one hand he pointed to heaven
and with the other hand he pointed to earth,
performing the lion's roar:
'Above heaven and below heaven I alone am honoured.'
Furthermore he said in the following gāthā:
My fate of being born in a womb has come to an end, /tsHin)/lg==
This is my very last rebirth. /s4in/lg==
I have already attained liberationlg==
And shall in return deliver the sentient beings. /s44a:jN/lg==
After he had spoken this gāthā
he accected nine dragons to spit water,
bathing the prince [in it].
After the prince had been bathed
he fell silent and did not speak,
and reverted to being like a regular baby."
Furthermore, according to the Zhōuyì jì, it says:
"In the 24th year of the King Zhāo's ascension to the throne, in the year jiǎyín [1027 B.C. !?]
on the eighth day of the fourth month,
the rivers, springs and ponds were suddenly overflowing
and the palaces, houses of the people, mountains, plains, and the earth were all shaking.
The light had five colors,
penetrating big and small (i.e. everything)
and permeating thrughout the whole world.
King Zhāo asked the Grand Scribe Sū Yóu:
'What kind of auspicious omen is this?'
Sū Yóu formally addressed the Emperor, saying:
'There is a great saint born in the Western region.'
The king asked further:
'How will this affect the world?'
Yóu said:
'Though at this time there will be no effect,
after another thousand years his reputation and teaching will spread to this country.'"240
This is how the auspicious event of Buddha's birth in the palace of King Jīngfàn in the city of Kapilavastu of Western India auspiciously influenced this country (i.e. China).
According to the Nidāna sūtra, it is said:
"When the prince reached the age of nineteen
he got fed up with the imperial palace.
His father, the king, was worried that he would renounce his home
and consequently he ordered to entertain him with flute-music. [?]
But the prince was not pleased.
He sat until the third watch of the night,242
until all the five hundred palace-ladies had fallen asleep.
At that time the God Śuddādhivāsa was in mid-air243
Expounding a gāthā, he told the prince:
The world is not pure and there are many delusionslg==
But nothing surpasses the nature (sex-appeal ?) of the women's body.lg==
Since wordly clothes are adornedlg==
Ignorance produce wordly desire.lg==
The person who is able to make the following investigation (or: have this type of understanding),lg==
Like a dream and like magic, there is not true realisty [in desires]lg==
Quicky gets rid of his ignorance and does not act in an unrestrained manner,lg==
And without fail he will attain liberation and the [dharma-]body of merit."246lg==
After that the deva at the window [showed his reverence and] folded his hands, addressing the prince:
"It is the right time to leave now."
After the prince had heard this gāthā
his mind produced [a feeling of] joy.
He secretly ordered Chandaka to get ready (i.e. saddle) the horse Kanthaka.
Four spirits lifted up its feet,
and the horse leapt over the city wall and they left for the northwest.
The prince thought:
'One who has renounced home should be equipped with [a heart of] great compassion
and if I do not leave behind traces of a horse,
the king is bound to accuse the servants [because of my leaving].'
He then left one horse trace at the northwest corner of the city wall
to let [the king] know that he left to the northwest soaring through the air.
The time [when this happened] corresponds with the middle of the night on the eighths day of the second month in the 42nd year of King Zhāo of the Zhōu, the year rénshēn (1009 B.C.) in our country.
According to a Vinaya text it is said:253
"After the prince had left
he arrived at Mt. Paṇdava in the country Magadha,
where he sat cross-legged (in Lotus-position) on a stone.
The following thought occurred to him:
'With what shall I shave away the hair on my head?'256
Just at the moment when this thought occurred to him
the god (deva) Jìngjū at once held up a knife in his hands.
The prince took it himself
and after he had finished shaving
the deva Jìngjū again held up an outer monks' robe which was made of unpatterned (màn 縵) silk in his hands;258
the prince then took off the clothes he had worn in former days,
and also took off his crown and handed them, together with the white horse and the other personal belongings over to Chandaka.259
to bring them back to the royal palace,
and tell the following gāthā to his father, the king:
Even though lovingly (with feelings of affection) we always could live together262
At the time when the end of life is reached (i.e. at the time of death) we happen to be separated.
I realize that this impermanence and short-lived period, ??
And therefore I now seek liberation."
At that time the prince ferociously put in effort in the mountain
and cultivated the Supreme Way.
Then he visited the place of Arādakālāma
where he studied the 'samādhi of no-function' for three years.
When he found out that [this method] was wrong he discarded it.
Next he went to the place of Udraka-rāmaputrá67
and for one year268 he practiced the highest state of concentration,269
and after he had found out that this method was wrong he also abandoned it.
He then proceeded to Mt. Gayajasīrsa
and together with the [other] heretics he daily ate one corn of hemp and one corn of wheat,
and carried on with this practice for six years.
When the practice as ascetic was about to be completed,

and below there was white mist streaming out horizontally in six paths.13
The Fourth Patriarch asked the Fifth Patriarch, saying:
"Do you understand this auspicious sign?"
The Fifth Patriarch said:
"Does that not mean that there will be one branch of the Buddha-dharma coming out horizontally (sidewise) among the disciples of the master?"
The Fourth Patriarch said:
"You understand my meaning.
You better stay here!
I shall cross over to the east of the Jiāng (i.e. Yangtze)."
He then arrived at the Yōuqī monastery at Mt. Niútóu.
He met several hundred monks none of whom looked like real Buddhists (had an aura of Buddhists);18
so he turned to a monk and asked him:

The monk said:

The Fourth Patriarch said:

The monk did not know what to anwer.

[Somebody] asked the master:
"As for speaking of somebody as a sage,
what dharma must he have cut off
and what dharma must he have obtained
so that we call him a sage?"
[The master] answered:
"[He who] has neither cut off a single dharma
nor obtained a single (new) dharma,
such a person is called a sage."
[The monk] asked furthermore:
"If he does not cut off and does not obtain [any dharma],
what difference is there from an ordinary person?"
The master said:
"There is a difference.
Why is that so?
All ordinary people have something to cut off (eliminate)
and falsely assuming that there is something to attain;
however, a sage who has realized his true mind has basically nothing to cut off (eliminate)
and nothing to attain.
Therefore [I] say there is a difference."
[The person] proceeded to ask:
"How can it be that the ordinary person has something to obtain and the sage has nothing to obtain?
What difference is there between obtaining and not obtaining?"
The master said:
"There is a difference,
and why is that so?
The ordinary person has something to obtain,
and therefore he is deluded (or: therefore there exists delusion);
the sage has nothing to obtain,
therefore he is not deluded.
If there is delusion then there is a difference,
If there is no delusion then there is no difference."
[The person] continued asking:
"If there is no difference,
on what criteria is the concept of 'sage' postulated?"
The master said:
"As for the concept of 'ordinary' and 'sage'
both are fake (provisional) names.
Among fake (provisional) names there is no opposition (dualism),
thus there is no difference.
It is like talking about the hair of a turtoise or the horn of a hare."
[The person] asked furthermore:
"If the sage is like the hair of a turtoise or the horn of a hare,
then [he] necessarily is non-existing.86
But what should we cause people to study then?"
The master replied:
"I said 'hair of a turtoise'
and did not say that there is no turtoise.
Why do you create these difficulties!"
[The person] added:
"[Well then], what does the turtle compare to?
And what does the hair compare to?"
The master said:
"The turtoise is a metaphor for the Buddhist truth
and the hair refers to the self.
Therefore the sage does not have a self, but he is in possession of the Way,
the ordinary person is not in possession of the Way but he has a self (ego).
Those who hold on to the notion of a self are like the hair of a turtle or the horn of a hare."
And with this the transmission of the dharma to Zhìyán came to an end.

Emperor Sùzōng ordered him to move to Jīngzhōu
where he resided in the Kāiyuán monastery.
A letter arrived from the master's native village,
reporting that his father and mother had both died.
The master thereupon entered the monk's hall and announced formally:
"My father and mother have both died,
and I ask the great assembly to recite the Móhēbórě."
The moment the great assembly had taken their seats
the master said:
"I troubled the great assembly
take care of yourselves."
The master died on the thirteenth day of the fifth month in the first year of the shàng-yuán era (760 A.D.)
and by imperial order he was bestowed with the post-humous title Grand Master Zhēnzōng ('True-doctrine') and the Bōrě ('Wisdoms') pagoda was erected for him.
At the time when the boy was living at home,
he never uttered a word
nor did he ever cross the bridge in front of the [village-] gate.
At the time when he reached the age of sixteen,
a Chán master came
and as soon as he saw him from afar,
he ran out and crossed the bridge in front of the gate,
welcomed him, made prostrations
and exchanged greetings with him.
His father, mother, [other] family members and neighbours from far and near all came
and said with surprise:
'This is unbelievable!
This boy,
from the time when he was born until he reached the age of sixteen,
has never been seen talking
or crossing the bridge in front of the gate.
But today, as soon he lay eyes on this monk,
he did all this!231
This boy is surely different from ordinary people!"
The boy thereupon adressed the Chán master:
"I beg you, master, to be merciful and accept me [as your student]
and save [this] one living being.
I definitely want to devote myself to [the] Chán [teaching] and become a monk."
The Chán master said:
"In this [Chán-] school of ours,
only legal heirs of a Silver-Wheel King
and grandsons of the Golden-Wheel King are entitled for the succession,
so that this teaching will not decline (in order not to destroy this style of teaching).
But you are a child of a man and woman from a small hamlet,
raised (or: begot) on the back of an ox.
How could you devote yourself to this school?
That's not a matter alloted to you by fate."
The boy said:
"I tell you, master:
'This teaching is iniversal
and without [the difference of] high and low (elevated and humble social position).'
How can you use words like these to impede my good intentions?
I beg you again, master, to bestow your compassion on me and accept me [as your student]!"
When the Chán master saw the boy behaving like this
he said to him:
"If you are [so determined] as this,
then you should not devote yourself to me to become a monk."
The child said:
"Whom shall I devote myself to in order to become a monk?
Please point out a teacher for me."
The Chán master said:
"Did you hear about [a place called] Cáoxī?"
The child answered:
"I do not know where Cáoxī is situated."
The Chán master said:
"In Guǎngnán, on Mt. Cáoxī,
there lives a teacher (spiritual mentor)
who is called the 'Sixth Patriarch'.
He instructed as many as 600 disciples.
Go there to become a monk.
I have never travelled to [Mt.] Tiāntái,240
so you have to go there on your own."
The boy then hid away in the [high] grass [?]
avoided his father and mother and then set out on his journey.
A three-days journey he would walk in two days
and a two-days journey he would walk in one day.
When he arrived in Cáoxī
he happened to meet the Patriarch just at the time of teaching.
He proceeded to show his reverence to him.
The Patriarch asked:
"Where do you come from?"
He answered:
"From just close by."
The Patriarch said:
"Where is your place of birth?"243
The boy said:
"Since I obtained this physical body,244 I have completely forgotten it."
The Patriarch waved with his hand and said:
"Come closer!"
The boy came closer.
The Patriarch said:
"Honestly speaking, where are you from?"
The boy said:
"I am a person from Zhè."245
The Patriarch said:
"For what purpose did you come here from so far away?"
The boy said:
"Firstly, it is hard to meet an enlightened master
and the right dharma is difficult to encounter;
I came especially to formally visit you, the Patriarch.
Secondly, I want to entrust myself to you in order to renounce home,
and beg you to bestow your mercy on me and accept me [as your student]."
The Patriarch said:
"I tell you: Do not renounce home!"
The boy said:
"Why do you talk like this?"
The master said:
"You will become a sagely and enlightened emperor [who shall rule] for sixty years without the use of weapons,
and you will be the only one to establish the imperial Buddha-dharma as guiding line (main prinicple)."
The boy said:
"I tell you, master!
Not only a period of sixty years,
even a period of one hundred years as emperor I do not want.
I beg the master to be merciful
and allow me to become a monk."
The master then rubbed the boy's forehead and gave him the following prediction:
"If you become a monk
then you alone will establish the Buddha in the world."[?]
And he proceeded to take him on [as his disciple].
After he had practiced for a period of over 40 years at Mt. Báiyá [White Cliff] in Nányáng,
he received an imperial order on the sixteenth day of the first month of the second year of the shàng-yúan era (762 A.D.).
Emperor Sùzōng ordered him to move to the capital [Cháng'ān]
and reside at the Western Chán compound of the Qiānfù Monastery;
afterwards he returned to the Guāngzhái Monastery.
The succeeding Emperors Sùzōng and Dàizōng
both personally received the Bodhisattva-precepts from him
and they bestowed the honorary title of 'National Master' on him.
A monk asked:
"How is the paramount meaning of the Buddha-dharma?"
The master said:
"In the Wénshū hall there are 10,000 Bodhisattvas."
The monk said:
"I do not understand."
The master said:
"Dàbēi [has] 1,000 arms and 1,000 eyes."
Once the master was sitting in meditation
when [Emperor] Sùzōng asked:
"What dharma did you attain?"
The master said:
"Does Your Majesty see the one cloud in the sky?"
The Emperor said:
"I see it."
The master said:
"Is it nailed up with a nail
or is it dangling (hanging down)?"
The Emperor asked:
"How about the ten-bodied Buddha (Regulator)?"
The master thereupon stood up and said:
"Do you understand?"
The Emperor said:
"[I] do not understand."
The master said:
"Hand me a jar with fresh water."
Dānyuán asked:
"Hundred years after the master (i.e. after you have passed away),
if there were a person asking about the ultimate principle,
how shall one talk to him?"
The master said:
"[You are] really (fundamentally) pitiful!
You should by all means get an amulet for protecting the body, what about that?"264
On the occasion when Emperor Sùzōng followed the servants who where carrying the master on their shoulders up the palace-hall, [??]
the master then looked up [to the Emperor], saying:
"Do you understand?"
The Emperor said:
"[I] do not."
The master said:
"I am tired today."
The Emperor asked:
"How about 'no-conflict samādhi'?"
The master said:
"You, the lay-supporter, walk, trampling on the head of Vairocana Buddha."
The Emperor said:
"What does it mean to walk trampling on the head of Vairocana Buddha?"
The master said:
"You do not realize your own pure dharma-body." [?]
One day, the master saw Dānyuán entering the dharma-hall.
The master thereupon let one foot dangle down.
Dānyuán then went out
and came back after a while.
The master said:
"What is the meaning of what happened just now?"270
[Dānyuán] answered:
"To whom shall I talk in order to attain it/find out?"
The master said:
"I ask you."
[Dānyuán] answered:
"Where do you see me?"
When Emperor Sùzōng inquired about something
the master did not look at the Emperor.
The Emperor said:
"I am the Son of Heaven (i.e. Emperor) over the whole country,
How can you be so special that you do not look at me at all?"(what's so special about you that you do not even give me a glance).
The master said:
"Does the Emperor see the empty space in front of his eyes?"
The Emperor said:
"[I] see [it]."
The master said:
"Did it ever blink at Your Majesty?"
Yú Jūnróng asked:
"When you stayed at Mt. Báiyá, how did you practice?"
The master called after the family's (servant) boy (acolyte)
and the boy came.
The master then rubbed the boy's head with his hand and said:
"Wide awake - straightforward words - wide awake,
Perfectly clear - straightforward words - perfectly clear; [??]
from now on, do not be deceived by people."
Zhāngfén from Nányáng asked:
"I have heard that there is [the doctrine according to which] 'non-sentient [objects] expound the dharma'
but I have not yet understood this matter.
I beg the master to explain it to me."
The master [Hùizhōng] said:
"'Non-sentient [objects] expound the dharma':
at the time when you listen [to them], only then you hear non-sentient objects expounding the dharma;
[but] only because they [i.e. non-sentient objects] are non-sentient, you can hear my teaching;
just go ahead and ask about the teaching of non-sentient objects!"
Zhāngfén said:
"As for now being restricted to expedient means which apply to sentient beings, [??]
how is the case with non-sentients?"
The master said:
"They [i.e. non-sentients/objects] are active in all processes of existence.
If commoners and sages both are without the slightest [notion of] arising and vanishing (birth and death),
then they have gone beyond consciousness
and do not belong to the category of 'sentient beings'.
Clearly they can see and perceive, but they do not grasp [for the object during this process];
therefore when the six sense organs are confronted with form (i.e. sense objects), they discriminate without consciousness."
At the time when the master was at [the place of] his fellow villager [Má]Gǔ,
Mágǔ came and went around (circumambulated) the master three times,
shaking his monk's staff once.
The master said:
"Since it is like this,
what use is there in seeing me again?"
Mǎgǔ shook his monk' staff once more.
The master scolded him, saying:
"This wild-fox spirit!"
Chángqìng commented on this, saying:
"What does the great person mean by this (lit. have what kind of mental activity)?"289
He commented on this further, saying:
"If it is not like this (if this is not the case),
how can I possibly recognize (know) the Preceptor?"[?]
Once the master and dharma-master Zǐcàn were discussing doctrinal issues together,
and after each of them had ascended their seats,
the dharma-master said:
"I request that you postulate a proposition
and I will refute it then."
The master said:
"How could there be such a thing/matter?"
The dharma-master said:
"I then ask [you] to postulate a proposition."
The master said:
"I have already postulated a proposition."
The dharma-master said:
"What proposition did you postulate?"
The master said:
"If you really do not understand it,
then it is beyond your intellectual horizon."291 (i.e. this is beyond your capacity)
Chángqìng commented on this, saying:
"The proposition of the master has been refuted."
Once there was an lecture master who came for a visit
and the master asked him:
"What is your occupation?"
He answered:
"As my occupation I lecture on the Diamond sūtra."
The master said:
"What are the first two Chinese characters [of the Diamond sūtra]?"
The lecture master answered:
"Rú shì (Like this)."
The master said:
"Like what (What is it)?"
The master asked the official Càn:
"What is the meaning [of the word] 'Buddha'?"
He answered:
"'Buddha means 'enlightened'."
The master said:
"Has the Buddha ever been deluded?"
He answered:
"He was never deluded."
The master said:
"Since he was never deluded,
what is the point of becoming enlightened?"
[The servant] was unable to answer.
The offical asked further:
"What is the meaning of the 'Real Mark'?"
The master said:
"Bring [me] what is empty (i.e. emptiness)."
[The servant] answered:
"What is empty cannot be attained."
The master said:
"If emptiness cannot be attained,
what's the point of asking about the true mark?"
Another time, when the master saw a monk coming,
he formed a circle with his hand
and in the middle of the circle he wrote:
"'字 [Chinese graph].'"
The monk was unable to answer.
At one time Wáng Yǒng asked:
"How does one attain liberation?"
The master said:
"If all dharmas are not reached [??]
at that very place one attains liberation."
Yǒng asked:
"If it is like this
then this is 'cutting off' [perception]
how could this be liberation?"
The master thereupon shouted:
"You, this fellow,
I said to you 'not be reached',
who said anything to you about 'cutting off'?"
Wáng Yǒng did not have anything further to say.
The Preceptor certainly knew that this man was an official [concerned with the] the three teachings.
Zhìxīn, a disciple of Wáng Yǒng, asked:
"How can one become a Buddha?"
The master said:
"As for Buddha and sentient beings,
the instant you let go of them (or: if you let go of them all together),
that very place is liberation.
[Zhìxīn] said further:
"How does one attain 'accordance'?"
The master said:
"Do not think about good and bad,
then you naturally can realize Buddha-nature."
[Zhìxīn] continued asking:
"How can one realize the dharma-body?"
[The master] said:
"By transcending the sphere of Pílúzhēnà (Vairocana)."
[Zhìxīn] said further;
"How can the pure dharma-body be transcended?"
The master said:
"Do not be attached to the search after Buddha."
[Zhìxīn] continued asking:
"Which one is Buddha?"
The master said:
"The very mind is the Buddha."
[Zhìxīn] asked furthermore:
"The mind has afflictions,
how can it be the Budddha?"
The master said:
"The nature of affliction is that they disappear by themselves."
[Zhìxīn] continued asking:
"How can it be that one does not [have to] cut off afflictions?"
The master said:
"Cutting off afflicitons is [associated with] followers of the Small Vehicle and Pratyeka-Buddhas
if one realizes that afflictions do not arise/are unborn,
then this is called mahā-nirvānNa (Great Nirvana).
At another occasion Emperor Dàizōng brought along a recluse from Mt. Dàbái to visit the master:
and said:
"This recluse has deep understanding.'312
The master asked:
"What kind of skills does he have?"
Dàizōng said:
"He knows the mountains,
he knows the earth,
he knows Chinese graphs
and he is able to count."
The Preceptor asked politely:
"The place where the recluse resided, is it a female mountain
or is it a male mountain?"
The recluse was silent for a long time, unable to answer.
[The master] asked furthermore:
"Do you know about the earth?"
The recluse said:
"I do."
The master then pointed to the earth (floor) in the palace-hall, saying
"What kind of earth is this?"
The recluse said:
"Allow me to count,
only then I will know it."
[The master] continued asking:
"Do you know Chinese graphs?"
[The recluse] answered:
The master deliniated the graph '一' ('one') on the ground
and asked:
"Which Chinese graph is this?"
[The recluse] answered:
"This is the graph '一' ('one') ."
The master said:
"If I attach the graph '一' ('one') to the ground (土)
then this is the graph 王 ('king'),
certainly not the graph '一' ('one')!"
[The master] asked furthermore:
"Can you calculate?"
[The recluse] answered:
"[I] can."
The master said:
"How much is three [times] seven?"
[The recluse] answered:
"You are making fun of me,
three [times] seven [is] twenty-one."
The master said:
"On the contrary, it is YOU who is mocking me.
Three [plus!!] seven is ten,
calling it twenty-one,
is that not mocking me?"
[The master] asked further:
"Which additional skills do you have?"
The recluse said:
"I have additional [skills]
but I really do not dare to answer."
The master said:
"Even if you understood everything
it would not be sufficient to be held in high esteem."
The master in turn told Emperor Dàizōng:
"Asking him about mountains he did not know mountains,
asking him abouth the earth, he did not know the earth,
asking him about Chinese graphs, he did not know Chinese graphs,
asking him to count, he was not able to count;
why did you bring this dumb fellow along?"
Dàizōng said to the recluse:
"Though I am in possession of the throne of the country
it is not my treasure;
the Preceptor [here] is my real treasure."
The mountain recluse said:
"Your Majesty really recognizes a precious person."
During the middle 10-day cycle of the tenth month318
all abbots (lecture masters) came to pay obeiscance to the master.
The master asked:
"Which colour does the grass outside the city walls have?"
[They] answered:
"It has yellow colour."319
The master then called for a young servant boy and asked him:
"Which colour does the grass outside the city walls have?"
[The boy] answered:
"[It] has yellow colour."
The master said:
"You lecture masters have knowledge of the scriptures and commentaries
[but] how does your understanding differ from that of this servant boy?"
The lecture masters in return asked the preceptor:
"Which colour does the grass outside the city walls have?"
The master said:
"Do you see the birds in the sky?"
The lecture masters said:
"You, the Preceptor, all the more do not make sense.
We wish that you instruct us how to get it right (or: how it really is)."[??]
In response the master called the lecture masters to come forward.
All the lecture masters came at once (or: all together) forward.
The master realized that the lecture masters did not understand,
he thereupon said with a sneer:
"All of you should return to their monasteries
and come back another day."
All the persons of great virtue left in silence.
The day after they came back.
"We want you to try to expound [the teaching] for us."
The master said:
"To understand is simply understand,
if you do not understand,
then, although [I] can expound [the teaching for you] you still won't be able to understand."
All the officials said:
"From the former National Masters onwards
there was not any of this kind of (crafty ??) eloquence which could resemble the master's."
The master said:
"The others acted take the nation as their master,
I am a master of the nation (i.e. National Master)."
All officials said:
"All of us
were deceitfully (pretentiously) acting as officials [advisors in religious matters].
and ourselves claimed to have knowledge of the scriptures and commentaries.
For those relying on the Chán school of others (here: of yours), this is without any relevance."
A visiting Chán-monk from the South raised the following question:327
"What about the mind of the ancient Buddha?"
The master said:
"Walls and rubble,
non-sentient objects [like those]
are all the mind of the ancient Buddha."
The visiting Chán-monk said:
"This is entirely contradictory to the scriptures!
That is why the Mahā-parinNirvāna sūtra says:
'It is different from non-sentient objects
like walls and rubble,
therefore it is called Buddha-nature.'
Now you state that all non-sentient objects are [part of the] Buddha mind.
Can you tell me whether mind and [Buddha-] nature are different or not?"331
The master said:
"For a deluded person they are different,
for an enlightened one they are one and the same."
The visiting Chán-monk said:
"Again you are contradicting the sūtras,
that is why a sūtra says:
'Good men! The [ordinary] mind is not Buddha-nature,
because Buddha-nature is permanent,
[whereas] the mind is not permanent.'
Now [you say], they are not different.
I wonder what you mean by this?"
The master said:
"You rely on words and not on the meaning.
Let us compare it to when during cold winter months
water solidifies into ice
and when the warm season arrives,
ice dissolves into water.
When living beings are in a state of delusion,
their [perfect] nature solidifies into mind;
when living beings get enlightened,
their mind dissolves into [Buddha-] nature.
If you insist that non-sentient objects do not have Buddha nature,
then the sūtras should not state:
'The Triple-World is mind-only,
all dharmas are consciousness[-only].'
Therefore the Avataṃsaka sūtra states:
'All dharmas in the Triple-World
are only produced by the mind.'
Now I ask you moreover:
Are non-sentient objects
included in the Triple-World
or apart from the Triple-World?
Are they mind
or are they not mind?
If they are not mind,
then the sūtras should not claim:
'the Triple-World is mind-only'.
If they are mind
then one should not state:
'non-sentient objects do not have Budda nature'.
You yourself are contradicting the scriptures,
not me!"
The Chán-guest said:
"Since non-sentient objects have mind,
do they expound the dharma?"
The master said:
"Distinctly they expound,
constantly they expound constantly, permanently they expound,
without any interruption (lit. time when they rest)!"
The Chán-guest remarked:
"Why can't I hear [it]?
The master answered:
"That you don't hear it
doesn't mean that there aren't others who do." (lit. cannot prevent others from hearing it)
Furthermore he said:
"Who is able to hear [it]?"
The master said:
"The sages can hear it."
The visiting Chán monk said:
"If it is like this then it is not in the living being's destiny (capacity) [to hear their teaching]."
The master said:
"I am expounding for the sake of living beings,
by no means for the sages."
The Chán guest said:
"I am ignorant
and do not hear the non-sentients' expounding of the dharma.
But you are a teacher of men and gods,
proclaiming the Perfection of Wisdom.
Can you hear non-sentients expound the dharma?"
The master said:
"I don't hear it either!"
[The Chán guest] continued asking:
"Why can't you hear it?"
The master said:
"You profit from that I do not hear non-sentients expound the dharma. [??]
If I could hear them expounding the dharma,
then I would be equal to the sages.
How could you be able to see me then
and manage to hear me expounding the dharma?"
The Chán-guest said:
"Will all sentient beings
in the end be able to hear non-sentients the dharma?"
The master said:
"If the sentient beings hear it,
than they would not be sentient beings."
The Chán-guest asked:
"[Does the doctrine of] 'non-sentient objects expound the dharma'
have a base in the canoncial scriptures?"
The master said:
"Words which do not refer to the scriptures
are not used by the Gentleman.
Did you not read the Amithaba sūtra, where it is said:
'Water, birds, the trees in the forest,
all recollect Buddhahood, Dharma and Sangha.'344
Birds are sentient beings,
but water and trees - how could they be sentient?
Furthermore the Avataṃsaka sūtra states:
'Lands345 teach, sentient beings expound,
everything in the three periods of time expounds.'
Living beings are sentient,
but certainly not [things like] lands!"
The Chán-guest said:
"Since non-sentient [objects] have Buddha-Nature,
what about sentient beings?"346
The master said:
"If non-sentient [objects] are like this,
how much more is that true for sentient beings!"
The Chán guest said:
"Assuming both sentient beings and non-sentient [objects] possess Buddha-nature:
in case one kills and eats a sentient being
then the fate of that person will be bound to the retribution of his sins.
In the case of damaging non-sentient objects,
eating things like the five kinds of grains, vegetables, fruits, etc.,
I have never heard that it involves sin,
and retribution for it (lit. mutual retribution)."
The master said:
"Sentient beings are [a case of] direct retribution.348
From beginningless kalpas349 onwards,
they are deluded and have perverted views,
they posit (assume there is) a self and things belonging to a self350 [?]
and harbour and are tied up be hate;
therefore they are subject to the retribution of resentment.
Non-sentient [objects] are [a case of] dependant retribution.
They are without perverted views and without a mind of resentment and hate;
therefore one does not talk about retribution [in their case]."
The guest said:
"In the teaching of the scriptures351 it is only written that sentient beings receive the prediction of complete enlightenment.
In future times
they will be able to become a Buddha
who will be called so and so.
I have not read about a passage where non-sentient objects receive the prediction of complete enlightenment,
and a place where they will become Buddha.
As for the thousand Buddhas of the xián-period,353
which one is a non-sentient object having become a Buddha.
Please point them out to me (please instruct me about this matter)."
The master said:
"I ask you now:
When, for example, the crown prince receives the throne,
does the crown prince [only] receive the throne
or does he receive everything in the country?"
[The Chán guest] answered:
"If the crown prince receives the throne,354
everything in the country belongs to the king,
how could he receive anything in addition to it!"
The master said:
"Now this matter is also like this:
if sentient beings receive the prediction of becoming a Buddha,
in the great chiliocosm
all countries,
belong to the body of Vairocana-Buddha.
Outside the Buddha-body
how could there exist additional non-sentient objects who receive the prediction?"
The guest said:
"All worlds are the Buddha-body
and all sentient beings dwell on this body;
they defecate and urinate [on it], soiling the Buddha-body,
they drill holes in it and trample on it.
How can they be without guilt!"
The master said:
"All living beings are the Buddha body.
Who could be guilty then?"
The guest said:
"The Buddha-body is unconditioned
and without anything obstructing it.
But now phenomena which are conditioned and are of obstructive nature manifest themselves as Buddha body,
is that not offending against the holy teaching?"
The master said:
"Now, haven't you read the Dà pǐn jīng:
'One cannot leave (seperate oneself from) the conditioned and talk about the unconditioned;
One cannot leave (seperate oneself from) the unconditioned and talk about the conditioned.'
Do you have faith that form is emptiness?"
[The guest] answered:
"Buddha's true words -
how could I dare not to believe in them?"
The master said:
"Since form is emptiness,
how can there be obstruction!"
[The guest] asked further:
"Living beings and Buddha being the same;
then, using the practice of the one Buddha,
all sentient beings are bound to be liberated at the same time.
Now you see that it is not like this -
wherein lies the meaning of tóng 同 'be same'"?
The master said:
"Have you not read about the meaning of the 'Six Marks' in the Avataṃsaka-sūtra:
'Amidst equality there is difference,
amidst difference there is equality;
amidst completion there is destruction,
amidst destruction there is completion;
in the whole there are the parts;
amidst the parts there is the whole.'
Even if sentient beings and Buddha have one and the same nature,
that does not prevent each individual from practicing and obtaining [Buddhahood] oneself.
To watch other people eat
does in the end not fill one's own stomach (in the end oneself does not feel satiated)!"
[The Chán guest] inquired further:
"A virtuous man of old said:
'The fresh and green bamboo,
are all true suchness,362
the densely growing crysanthemums,
none of them is not wisdom (prajña).'

[The Chán guest] furthermore raised the following question:
